The language of this idiomatic expression probably refers back to [Jer 49:36](../../jer/49/36.md). You may want to include this information in a footnote. Alternate translation: “the four extremities of the earth" or "the four directions of the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

### 144,000

The number 144,000 is twelve times twelve thousand and has some type of symbolic sense that the translator does not need to render the number. The number represents 12,000 from twelve tribes of Israel.

### Seven trumpets

Seven angels blow seven trumpets in Revelation 8:2-11:19. Trumpets are instruments for producing music or for calling people to gather together for an announcement or meeting. See how you translated "trumpet" in [Revelation 1:10](../01/10.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

### Incense

The term "incense" refers to a mixture of fragrant spices that is burned to produce smoke that has a pleasant smell. God commanded that the Israelites burn incense as an offering to him. If your readers would not be familiar with what incense is, you could use a general expression in your translation. Alternate translation: “pleasant smoke" or "fragrant spices” or “good-smelling plants" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Passive voice

John uses the passive voice several times in this chapter. This hides who performs the action. This will be difficult to convey if the translator’s language does not have a passive voice. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

### Similes

In verses 8 and 10, John uses similes to try to describe the images he sees in the vision. He compares the images to everyday things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

The pronoun **he** refers to the Lamb of the previous verse and in the immediate context. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: “the Lamb opened” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/writing-pronouns]])
See how you translated **seal** in [Revelation 5:1](../05/01.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

This is the last of the seven seals on the scroll. The word **seventh** is an ordinal number. Alternate translation: “the next seal” or “the final seal” or “seal number seven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Here, **there there was silence** means there was complete silence or lack of sound for a short period of time in heaven. The length of the quiet time is not really significant here. The particularly significant aspect for the translator to render is that heaven was quiet during a brief period of time. Alternate translation: “there was no sound" or “it was completely quiet”

Quote: τοὺς ἑπτὰ ἀγγέλους, οἳ ἐνώπιον τοῦ Θεοῦ ἑστήκασιν
Note: Interpreters often link the **seven angels** here with the **seven spirits** in [Revelation 1:4](../01/10.md) and [Revelation 4:5](../04/05.md). This connection seems logical, but it is not explicit in the text.

Each of the seven angels were given one trumpet. This could mean: (1) God gave them seven trumpets. (2) the Lamb gave them seven trumpets. If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God gave seven trumpets to them" or "Jesus gave seven trumpets to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Here, **trumpets** are instruments for producing music or for calling people to gather together for an announcement or meeting. See how you translated "trumpet" in [Revelation 1:10](../01/10.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
See how you translated **altar** in [Revelation 6:9](../06/09.md). Alternate translation: “the cultic furniture" or "the offering stand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

The term **censor** refers to a container, usually a metal bowl, in which one burns incense, most often during a religious or cultic ceremony. Usually a **censor** had a handle so that a priest could carry it to an altar, as in this context. Incense, which is placed in the **censor**, is a mixture of fragrant spices that is burned to produce smoke that has a pleasant smell. If your readers would not be familiar with what a **censor** is, you could use a general expression in your translation. Alternate translation: “gold incense container" or "gold incense bowl" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Here, **was given** could indicate that: (1) God gave much incense. (2) the Lamb gave much incense. If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God gave much incense to him" or "Jesus gave much incense to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

The term **incense** refers to a mixture of fragrant spices that is burned to produce smoke that has a pleasant smell. God commanded that the Israelites burn incense as an offering to him. If your readers would not be familiar with what incense is, you could use a general expression in your translation. Alternate translation: “pleasant smoke" or "fragrant spices” or “good-smelling plants" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
Alternate translation: "he would offer the incense" or “he would give it"

See how you translated **altar** in [Revelation 6:9](../06/09.md). This **altar** here appears to be distinct or different from the one mentioned earlier in this verse. However, such a distinction is not entirely clear. It seems preferable that the translator not attempt to indicate any relation between the two occurrences of **altar** in this verse, but only separately render the two distinct occurrences of **altar**. Alternate translation: “the golden cultic furniture" or "the golden offering stand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Here, **the smoke of the incense** literally is the incense smoke that went up from burning the incense. Alternate translation: "the smoke that rose from the incense burning" or "the smoke that went up from the incense burning"

Here, **the hand** refers to the golden censer in the angel's hand. If it would be helpful in your language, you make it clear that the incense was burning within a censer and not directly touching the hand of the angel. Alternate translation: “from the censer in the angel's hand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

This expression **before God** refers to the presence of God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “toward God” or "to where God was" or "into the presence of God"(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: καὶ εἴληφεν ὁ ἄγγελος τὸν λιβανωτόν, καὶ ἐγέμισεν αὐτὸν ἐκ τοῦ πυρὸς τοῦ θυσιαστηρίου
Note: Here, **the fire** probably refers to burning coals. The angel took live coals from the altar and put them in a censer before throwing the burning incense and the live coals upon the earth. If it would be clearer for your readers, in your translation you could just refer to the “censer for burning incense". Alternate translation: "And the angel took the incense container and filled it with the fire of the altar" or "And the angel took the censor and filled it with the burning coals of the altar" or "And the angel took the censor and filled it with coals of fire from the altar" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
See how you translated **thunder** in [Revelation 4:5](../04/05.md).
See how you translated **earthquake** in [Revelation 6:12](../06/12.md).
Alternate translation: "holding the seven trumpets"

Here, **hail** usually refers to lumps of frozen water that fall from the sky. Hail that comes down from the sky is in the form of balls or chunks of ice called “hailstones.” Usually hailstones are small (only a few centimeters wide), but sometimes there are hailstones that are as big as 20 centimeters wide and that weigh over a kilogram. If your readers would not be familiar with what hail is, you could use a general expression in your translation. Alternate translation: “hailstones” or "ice balls" or "balls of ice" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the angel threw the hail and fire mixed with blood down onto the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: τὸ τρίτον τῆς γῆς κατεκάη, καὶ τὸ τρίτον τῶν δένδρων κατεκάη, καὶ πᾶς χόρτος χλωρὸς κατεκάη
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “it burned up a third of the earth, a third of the trees, and all the green grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: τὸ τρίτον τῆς γῆς κατεκάη, καὶ τὸ τρίτον
Note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. Alternate translation: “one out of every three parts of the earth was burned up, and one out of every three parts" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

Here the expression **all the green grass** refers to "all plants" or "all vegetation". The context suggests that all the vegetation that grew on this particular one third section of the earth's surface was destroyed. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “all the green plants” or "all the green vegetation" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The word **second** is an ordinal number. Alternate translation: “the next angel” or “angel number two” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

The point of this comparison is that the huge solid object had a size and shape of a large mountain. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: “something as huge as a great mountain burning with fire" or “something as large as a great mountain burning with fire"\n(See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: ὡς ὄρος μέγα πυρὶ καιόμενον, ἐβλήθη
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God threw something like a great mountain burning with fire” or "the angel threw something like a great mountain burning with fire" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ἐγένετο τὸ τρίτον τῆς θαλάσσης αἷμα
Note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. If your readers would misunderstand the fraction **a third**, you can explain it in translation. Alternate translation: “it was like the sea was divided into three parts, and one of those parts became blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

Quote: ἐγένετο τὸ τρίτον τῆς θαλάσσης αἷμα
Note: The clause compares the a third of the earth's sea to blood in some way. The clause seems to mean that the color of the water became red in color like blood. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: “a third of the sea turned red" or "a third of the sea appeared red" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: τὸ τρίτον τῶν κτισμάτων τῶν ἐν τῇ θαλάσσῃ τὰ ἔχοντα ψυχάς, καὶ τὸ τρίτον
Note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. If your readers would misunderstand the fraction **a third**, you can explain it in translation. Alternate translation: “one out of every three creatures having life in the sea died and one out of every three" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

Quote: τῶν κτισμάτων τῶν ἐν τῇ θαλάσσῃ τὰ ἔχοντα ψυχάς
Note: Here, **of the creatures having life in the sea** refers to the earth's marine animals or the earth's marine life. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “of the things living in the sea” or “of the fish and other animals that live in the sea” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
The word **third** is an ordinal number. Alternate translation: “the next angel” or “angel number three” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: ἔπεσεν ἐκ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ ἀστὴρ μέγας, καιόμενος ὡς λαμπάς
Note: The fire of the **huge star** looked similar to the fire of **a torch**. John is comparing the similarity of a torch's fire to the appearance of fire when the huge star shines or blazes in this context. Alternate translation: “a huge star that was blazing like a torch fell from the sky” or “a huge star fell from the sky, shining as a torch” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

A **torch** a stick with one end lit on fire to provide light. If your readers would not be familiar with what a **torch** is, in your translation you could use the name of a comparable object in your culture or you could use a general expression. Alternate translation: “a lamp" or "a lantern" or "a firebrand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: τὸ τρίτον τῶν ποταμῶν, καὶ ἐπὶ τὰς πηγὰς τῶν ὑδάτων
Note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts of fresh water sources on the earth, such as rivers or fountains. If your readers would misunderstand the fraction **a third**, you can explain it in translation. Alternate translation: “one out of every three rivers and one out of every three springs of water" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

Here, **the springs of water** refers to all the springs or fountains of fresh water on the earth's surface. The context makes clear that a third of all the fresh water sources on the earth's surface are in view here. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “the fresh water sources" or "the fountains of fresh water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: τὸ ὄνομα τοῦ ἀστέρος λέγεται ὁ Ἄψινθος
Note: **Wormwood** is a drug that is made from an aromatic shrub that tastes bitter. When one added the **Wormwood** drug to water, it turned the water sour or bitter to the taste. People often made medicine from **Wormwood**, but many people considered **Wormwood** to be poisonous. Alternate translation: “the name of the star is Bitterness” or “the name of the star is Bitter Medicine” or "“the name of the star is Bitter Drug” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: ἐγένετο τὸ τρίτον τῶν ὑδάτων εἰς ἄψινθον
Note: The bitter taste of the water is spoken of as if it were **wormwood**. Alternate translation: “a third of the waters became bitter like wormwood” or “a third of the waters became bitter” or "a third of the waters turned bitter" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. If your readers would misunderstand the fraction **a third**, you can explain it in translation. Alternate translation: “one out of every three parts" or "one of three parts" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

John uses the masculine word men in a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use a term in your language that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: “the people” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

Quote: ἀπέθανον ἐκ τῶν ὑδάτων, ὅτι ἐπικράνθησαν
Note: Here, **died from the waters** means that the people who drank the water died from the fact that the water became bitter or poisonous. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “died from drinking the waters that became bitter” or “died when they drank the bitter water” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
The word **fourth** is an ordinal number. Alternate translation: “the next angel” or “angel number four” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: ἐπλήγη τὸ τρίτον τοῦ ἡλίου, καὶ τὸ τρίτον τῆς σελήνης, καὶ τὸ τρίτον τῶν ἀστέρων
Note: John is speaking as if God struck or hit the sun, moon, and stars with a great force. John means that the sun, moon, and stars suffered an injury or damage, in a metaphorical way. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. "God damaged a third of the sun, and a third of the moon and a third of the stars" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who did the action, but the context suggests that it was God. Alternate translation:\n"God struck a third of the sun, and a third of the moon and a third of the stars" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: τὸ τρίτον τοῦ ἡλίου, καὶ τὸ τρίτον τῆς σελήνης, καὶ τὸ τρίτον τῶν ἀστέρων; ἵνα σκοτισθῇ τὸ τρίτον
Note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. If your readers would misunderstand the fraction **a third**, you can explain it in translation. Alternate translation: “one out of every three parts" or "one of three parts" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

The phrase **a third of then turned dark** could mean: (1) one third of the time, they were dark. (2) one third of the sun, one third of the moon, and one third of the stars became dark. The first option seems more likely. If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “a third of them did not shine" or "a third of them did not give light" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ἡ ἡμέρα μὴ φάνῃ τὸ τρίτον αὐτῆς, καὶ ἡ νὺξ ὁμοίως
Note: Here, **likewise** means that the same changes that happened to the sun, the moon, and the stars during the day also happened to them during the night. Both changes probably describe the duration of the light from the sun, the moon, and the stars as being shorter in duration. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “there was no light during one third of the day and one third of the night” or “they did not shine during one third of the day and one third of the night” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here, **mid-heaven** means relatively high in the sky. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “one eagle flying high in the sky" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: ἑνὸς ἀετοῦ πετομένου ἐν μεσουρανήματι, λέγοντος φωνῇ μεγάλῃ
Note: John speaks of a flying eagle as if it were a human speaking with a human voice. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “one eagle flying in the mid-heaven, speaking in a loud voice" or “one eagle flying in the mid-heaven, announcing in a loud voice" (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

The exclamation **Woe, woe, woe** expresses horror and dismay at the horrible suffering that comes upon the people of the earth. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “disaster" or "calamity" or "misfortune" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: ἐκ τῶν λοιπῶν φωνῶν τῆς σάλπιγγος τῶν τριῶν ἀγγέλων τῶν μελλόντων σαλπίζειν
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “because the three angels who have not yet sounded their trumpets are about to sound them” or “because the three angels who have not yet blown their trumpets are about to blow them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Revelation 9 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

### Outline of Chapter Nine of Revelation within 8:2-11:19

## The Seven Trumpets (8:2-11:19)

I. The Sounding of the Seven Trumpets (8:2-11:19)

A. The Prayers of God's People to Begin the Seven Trumpets (8:2-6)
B. The First Trumpet (8:7)
C. The Second Trumpet (8:8-9)
D. The Third Trumpet (8:10-11)
E. The Fourth Trumpet (8:12-13)
F. The Fifth Trumpet (9:1-12)
G. The Sixth Trumpet (9:13-21)
H. Preparations for the Seventh Trumpet (10:1-11:14)
   1. John eats the Book in an Angel's Hand (10:1-11)
   2. John measures the Temple and the Second Woe occurs (11:1-14)
I. The Seventh Trumpet (11:15-19)

In this chapter, John continues to describe what happens when angels sound seven trumpets. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])


## Special concepts in this chapter


### Woe



John describes several “woes” in the Book of Revelation. This chapter begins to describe three “woes” announced at the end of Chapter 8. Woes signify calamity, disaster, or a terrible event.


### Seven trumpets

Seven angels blow seven trumpets in Revelation 8:2-11:19. Trumpets are instruments for producing music or for calling people to gather together for an announcement or meeting. See how you translated "trumpet" in [Revelation 1:10](../01/10.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

### Animal imagery

This chapter includes several animals: locusts, scorpions, horses, lions, and snakes. Animals convey different qualities or traits. For example, a lion is powerful and dangerous. Translators should use the same animals in their translation if possible. If the animal is unknown, one with similar qualities or traits should be used.

### Locusts

The locusts are insects that fly together in large groups. People fear them because they can eat up the leaves in gardens and on trees. If your readers would not be familiar with what locusts are, in your translation you could use the name of a similar flying insect in your culture, or you could use a general expression. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

### Bottomless pit

This image is seen several times in the Book of Revelation. It is a picture of hell as being inescapable and the opposite direction as heaven. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/hell]])

### Abaddon and Apollyon

“Abaddon” is a Hebrew word. “Apollyon” is a Greek word. Both words mean “Destroyer.” John used the sounds of the Hebrew word and wrote them with Greek letters. The ULT and UST write the sounds of both words with English letters. Translators are encouraged to transliterate these words using the letters of the target language. The original Greek readers would have understood “Apollyon” to mean “Destroyer.” So translators may also supply what it means in the text or in a footnote. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-transliterate]])

### Repentance

Despite great signs, people are described as not repenting and so remain in their sin. People refusing to repent are also mentioned in Chapter 16. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Simile

John uses many similes in this chapter. They help to describe the images that he sees in his vision. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

### Generic Sense

Several times in this chapter John uses the masculine word men in a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use a term in your language that is clearly inclusive of both men and women such as “people” or “humanity.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

See how you translated **angel** in [Revelation 8:2](../08/02.md). If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use a cardinal number here or an equivalent expression. Alternate translation: “angel number five” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: καὶ ἐδόθη αὐτῷ ἡ κλεὶς τοῦ φρέατος τῆς Ἀβύσσου
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “{Someone} gave the key to the shaft of the abyss” or “{the star} received the key to the shaft of the abyss” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

As the General Notes to this chapter discuss, the term abyss literally means a bottomless pit, and here it describes a place of punishment. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could translate the term with an explanatory phrase. Alternate translation: “the deep pit where God punishes demons” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
See how you translated the term abyss in [Revelation 9:1](../09/01.md).

A **huge furnace** was a big oven that burned wood or coal to make bread, pottery, or even to smelt metals like iron. Often furnaces would give off a great amount of thick, dark **smoke**. If your readers would not be familiar with what a furnace is, in your translation you could use the name of a comparable object in your culture, or you could use a general expression. Alternate translation: “huge kiln" or "huge oven" or "huge stove” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

The point of this comparison is the **huge furnace** gives off a great amount of thick, dark **smoke**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: “like the great amount of smoke that comes from a huge furnace” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

If your language does not use this passive form **were darkened**, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “became dark” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

The **locusts** are insects that fly together in large groups. People fear them because they can eat up the leaves in gardens and on trees. If your readers would not be familiar with what **locusts** are, in your translation you could use the name of a similar flying insect in your culture, or you could use a general expression. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who did the action, it is clear from the context that it was God. Alternate translation: “authority was given to them” or "God gave to them power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ἐδόθη αὐταῖς ἐξουσία, ὡς ἔχουσιν ἐξουσίαν οἱ σκορπίοι
Note: These **scorpions** have the ability to sting and poison people. You can include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: “ability was given to them as scorpions have power" or "they have the ability to sting people as scorpions do” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
A scorpion is a small insect with a poisonous stinger on its tail. Its sting is extremely painful and the pain lasts a long time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The text does not say who **told** these locusts to not damage the earth's vegetation, but it implies that God commanded the locusts to not damage the world's vegetation. Alternate translation: “God told them” or “God commanded them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

John is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: “but only to harm the men” “but only to damage the men”(See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

As the General Notes to this chapter discuss, here and in several other places in this chapter John uses the masculine word men in a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use a term in your language that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: “the people” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

Here, **seal** refers to a tool that is used to press a mark onto a wax seal. In this case the tool would be used to put a mark on God’s people. If your readers would not be familiar with what a **forehead** is, in your translation you could use the name of a comparable term for **forehead** in your culture or you could use a general expression. Alternate translation: “brows” or "temples" or "frons" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: “as the torment of a scorpion when it would sting a man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

If your readers would not be familiar with what a **scorpion** is, in your translation you could use the name of a comparable insect or animal in your culture. Alternate translation: “stinging insect” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
See how you translated this in [Revelation 9:4](../09/04.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
See how you translated this in [Revelation 9:4](../09/04.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **death**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: “end of living" or “to live no more” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

John is speaking figuratively of **death** as if it were a person or animal that could run away or can flee. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: “they cannot die” or “they will not die” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

See how you translated this in [Revelation 9:4](../09/04.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

See how you translated a similar phrase in [Revelation 9:6](../09/06.md). Alternate translation: “with stingers like scorpion stingers” or “with stingers that could cause terrible pain as scorpion stingers can” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “the angel released the four angels who had been prepared for that hour and day and month and year” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

# Revelation 10 General Notes

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Seven thunders

John here describes the seven thunders as making sounds that he could understand as words. However, translators should use their normal word for “thunder” when translating these verses. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])

### “The mystery of God”

This refers to some aspect of the hidden plan of God. It is not necessary to know what this mystery is to translate it. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/reveal]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Simile

John uses similes to help him describe the face, legs, and voice of the mighty angel. Translators should understand other objects in this chapter, such as the rainbow and the cloud, with their normal meanings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

# General Information:\n\nJohn begins to describe a vision of a mighty angel holding a scroll. In John’s vision he is viewing what is happening from earth. This takes place between the blowing of the sixth and seventh trumpets.

John speaks of the angel as if he were wearing **a cloud** as his clothing. This expression may be understood as metaphor. However, because very unusual things were often seen in visions, it might be understood as a literally true statement in its context. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: τὸ πρόσωπον αὐτοῦ ὡς ὁ ἥλιος
Note: John compares the brightness of **his face** with the brightness of **the sun**. Alternate translation: “his face was bright like the sun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: οἱ πόδες αὐτοῦ ὡς στῦλοι πυρός
Note: Here, **feet** refers to the legs. Alternate translation: “his legs were like pillars of fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “then the angel shouted”
The **seven thunders** are described as if they were people who could speak. Alternate translation: “the seven thunders made a loud noise” or “the thunder sounded very loudly seven times”
This may refer to thunder occurring **seven** times, yet being spoken of as if it were **seven** different **thunders**.

Quote: καὶ ἤκουσα φωνὴν ἐκ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ
Note: Here, **voice** refers to words spoken by someone other than the angel. Alternate translation: “but I heard someone speaking from heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: ἦρεν τὴν χεῖρα αὐτοῦ τὴν δεξιὰν εἰς τὸν οὐρανόν
Note: He **raised his right hand to heaven** to show that he was swearing by God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: ὤμοσεν τῷ ζῶντι εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων
Note: Alternate translation: “and he asked that what he was going to say would be confirmed by the one who lives forever and ever”

Quote: τῷ ζῶντι εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων
Note: Here, **the one who lives forever and ever** refers to God.
Alternate translation: “There will be no more waiting” or “God will not delay”

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “God will accomplish his mystery” or “God will complete his secret plan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nJohn hears the voice from heaven, which he had heard in [Revelation 10:4](../10/04.md), speak to him again.

Quote: ἡ φωνὴ ἣν ἤκουσα ἐκ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ
Note: Here, **voice** refers to the speaker. Alternate translation: “the one I heard speak from heaven” or “the one who had spoken to me from heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
John heard.
Alternate translation: “the angel said to me”
This refers to a bad taste from the **stomach** after eating something that is not good. Alternate translation: “it will make your stomach sour”

Here, **tongues** refers to the people who speak the languages. Alternate translation: “many language communities” or “many groups of people who speak their own languages” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Revelation 11 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 15 and 17-18.

### Woe

John describes several “woes” in the book of Revelation. This chapter describes a second and third “woe” announced at the end of Chapter 8.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Gentiles

The word “Gentiles” here refers to ungodly people groups and not Gentile Christians. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/godly]])

### Two witnesses

Scholars have suggested many different ideas about these two witnesses. Translators do not need to understand this passage to accurately translate it. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

### Bottomless pit

This image is seen several times in the Book of Revelation. It is a picture of hell as being inescapable and the opposite direction as heaven. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/hell]])

# General Information:\n\nJohn begins to describe a vision about receiving a measuring rod and two witnesses that God appointed. This vision also takes place between the blowing of the sixth and seventh trumpets.

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “sSomeone gave me a reed like a measuring rod” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here, **me** refers to John.
Alternate translation: “count those who worship in the temple”
To **trample** to treat something as worthless by walking on it.

You can make it explicit why they will wear **sackcloth**. Alternate translation: “wearing rough mourning clothes” or “wearing scratchy clothes to show that they are very sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

# Revelation 12 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 10-12.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Serpent

The Book of Revelation uses imagery from the Old Testament. For example, John refers to Satan as the serpent. This image comes from the account of the Garden of Eden when Satan tempted Eve. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “A great sign was seen in heaven”

By using the passive voice here, John does not say who saw this great sign in heaven. The translation may be difficult when the subject is unclear, if your language does not have a passive voice. Many English translations use the past tense here and say “A great sign appeared in heaven.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])
# General Information:\n\nJohn begins to describe a woman who appears in his vision.

Quote: γυνὴ περιβεβλημένη τὸν ἥλιον, καὶ ἡ σελήνη ὑποκάτω τῶν ποδῶν αὐτῆς
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “a woman who was wearing the sun and had the moon under her feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nJohn describes a dragon that appears in his vision.
The **dragon** was a large, fierce reptile, like a lizard. For Jewish people, it was a symbol of evil and chaos. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
See how you translated this in [Revelation 8:7](../08/07.md). Alternate translation: “one third” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])

Quote: ποιμαίνειν πάντα τὰ ἔθνη ἐν ῥάβδῳ σιδηρᾷ
Note: Here, ruling harshly is spoken of as ruling **with an iron rod**. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Revelation 2:27](../02/27.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἡρπάσθη τὸ τέκνον αὐτῆς πρὸς τὸν Θεὸν
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “God quickly took her child to himself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

The **dragon** was a large, fierce reptile, like a lizard. For Jewish people, it was a symbol of evil and chaos. The dragon is also identified in verse 9 as “the devil or Satan.” See how you translated this in [Revelation 12:3](../12/03.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])

Quote: οὐδὲ τόπος εὑρέθη αὐτῶν ἔτι ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ
Note: Alternate translation: “so the dragon and his angels could no longer stay in heaven”

# Revelation 13 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the words of verse 10, which are from the Old Testament.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Similes

John uses many similes in this chapter. They help to describe the images that he sees in his vision. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Unknown animals

John uses different animals to try to describe what he saw. Some of these animals may not be known in the target language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

# Revelation 14 General Notes

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Harvest

Harvest is when people go out to gather ripe food from plants. Jesus used this as a metaphor to teach his followers that they need to go and tell other people about him so those people can be part of God’s kingdom. This chapter uses the metaphor of two harvests. Jesus gathers in his people from the whole earth. Then an angel gathers in wicked people whom God will punish. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

# Revelation 15 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

In this chapter, John describes events and pictures that occur in heaven.

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 3-4.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### “Victorious over the beast”

These people are spiritually victorious. While most spiritual battles cannot be seen, the Book of Revelation pictures spiritual battles as openly occurring. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/spirit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])

### “The temple having the tent of witness, was open in heaven”

Scripture elsewhere indicates the earthly temple copied God’s perfect dwelling place in heaven. Here John seems to refer to God’s heavenly dwelling place or temple. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])

### Songs

The Book of Revelation often describes heaven as a place where people sing. They worship God with songs. This illustrates that heaven is a place where God is always worshiped.

# Revelation 16 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

This chapter continues the vision of chapter 15. Together they give the seven plagues that complete the wrath of God. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wrath]])

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 5-7.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### “I heard a loud voice call out of the temple”

This is the same temple that was mentioned in chapter 15.

### Seven bowls of God’s wrath

This chapter reveals severe judgments. They are pictured as angels pouring out seven bowls of God’s wrath. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

The tone of this chapter is meant to astonish the reader. Translations should not minimize the vivid language expressed in this chapter.

### Armageddon

This is a Hebrew word. It is the name of a place. John used the sounds of the Hebrew word and wrote them with Greek letters. Translators are encouraged to transliterate it using the letters of the target language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-transliterate]])

# Revelation 17 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

This chapter begins to describe how God will destroy Babylon.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Prostitute

Scripture often pictures idolatrous Jews as adulterous people and sometimes as prostitutes. This is not the reference here. The translator should allow this illustration to be vague. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])

### Seven hills

This possibly refers to the city of Rome, which was known as the city on seven hills. However, the translator should not attempt to identify Rome in the translation.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

John uses many different metaphors in this chapter. He explains some of their meanings, but allows them to remain relatively unclear. The translator should attempt to do the same. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “The beast you saw existed, does not exist now, but is about to come up”

This and similar phrases in this chapter contrast the beast with Jesus. Jesus is called “the one who is, and who was, and who is to come” elsewhere in the Book of Revelation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

### Paradox

A paradox is a true statement that appears to describe something impossible. This sentence in 17:11 is a paradox: “the beast … is itself also an eighth king; but it is one of those seven kings.” The translator should not attempt to resolve this paradox. It should remain a mystery. ([Revelation 17:11](../rev/17/11.md))

# Revelation 18 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 1-8.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Prophecy

The angel prophesies about Babylon falling, which here means being destroyed. It is spoken of as having already happened. This is common in prophecy. It emphasizes that the coming judgment will certainly happen. The angel also prophesies that the people will lament over Babylon falling. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-apocalyptic]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors

Prophecy frequently uses metaphors. This chapter has a slightly different apocalyptic style than the Book of Revelation overall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nAnother angel comes down from heaven and speaks. This is a different angel than the one in the previous chapter, who spoke about the prostitute and the beast.
The angel speaks of **Babylon** having been destroyed as if it had fallen. See how you translated this in [Revelation 14:8](../14/08.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The angel speaks of the city of Babylon as if it were a prostitute. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Here, **the nations** is a metonym for the people of those nations. Alternate translation: “the people of all the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: ἐκ τοῦ οἴνου τοῦ θυμοῦ τῆς πορνείας αὐτῆς, πέπτωκαν
Note: Here, drinking **from the wine of her immoral passion** is a symbol for participating in her sexually immoral passion. Alternate translation: “have become sexually immoral like her” or “have become drunk like her in sexual sin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
This may well have a double meaning: literal sexual immorality and also the worship of false gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Babylon is spoken of as if it were a prostitute who has caused other people to sin along **with her**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
A merchant is a person who sells things.

Quote: ἐκ τῆς δυνάμεως τοῦ στρήνους αὐτῆς
Note: Alternate translation: “because she spent so much money on sexual immorality”
Here, **voice** refers to the speaker, which is probably either Jesus or the Father. Alternate translation: “someone else” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: ἐκολλήθησαν αὐτῆς αἱ ἁμαρτίαι ἄχρι τοῦ οὐρανοῦ
Note: The voice speaks of Babylon’s **sins** as if they were objects that could form a pile. Alternate translation: “her sins are so many they are like a pile that reaches heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This does not mean that God **remembered** something he had forgotten. See how you translated “called to mind” in [Revelation 16:19](../16/19.md). Alternate translation: “has thought of” or “has started to pay attention to”

Quote: ἀπόδοτε αὐτῇ ὡς καὶ αὐτὴ ἀπέδωκεν
Note: The voice speaks of punishment as if it were repayment. Alternate translation: “Punish her as she has punished others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The voice speaks of punishment as if it were repayment. Alternate translation: “punish her twice as much” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἐν τῷ ποτηρίῳ ᾧ ἐκέρασεν, κεράσατε αὐτῇ διπλοῦν
Note: The voice speaks of causing others to suffer as preparing strong wine for them to drink. Alternate translation: “prepare for her the wine of suffering that is twice as strong as what she made for others” or “make her suffer twice as much as she made others suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here, **mix double** could mean: (1) they should prepare twice the amount. (2) they should make it twice as strong.
Alternate translation: “the people of Babylon glorified themselves”

Quote: ὅτι ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ αὐτῆς λέγει
Note: Here, **heart** is a metonym for a person’s mind or thoughts. Alternate translation: “For she says to herself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
She claims to be a ruler, having her own authority. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
She implies that she will not be dependent on other people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Experiencing mourning is spoken of as seeing **mourning**. Alternate translation: “I will never mourn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Existing in the future is spoken of as coming. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Being burned up by fire is spoken of as being eaten up **by fire**. Alternate translation: “she will be completely burned up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “fire will completely burn her up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
# General Information:\n\nIn these verses the word **her** refers to the city of Babylon.
Alternate translation: “sinned sexually and did whatever they wanted just as the people of Babylon did”

Quote: διὰ τὸν φόβον τοῦ βασανισμοῦ αὐτῆς
Note: If your readers would misunderstand the abstract noun **torment**, you can express it with a verb. Alternate translation: “because they were afraid that they would be tormented like Babylon” or “because they were afraid that God would torment them as he torments Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The word **Woe** is repeated for emphasis.
Existing in the present is spoken of as having **come**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “mourn for the people of Babylon”
See how you translated these in [Revelation 17:4](../17/04.md). Alternate translation: “many kinds of expensive stones”
The **fine linen** is an expensive cloth made from flax. See how you translated “linen” in [Revelation 15:6](../15/06.md).

Purple cloth is a very dark red cloth that was very expensive at that time. Silk is a soft, strong cloth made from the fine string that silkworms make when they make their cocoons. Scarlet cloth was an expensive red cloth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
Alternate translation: “all kinds of containers made of ivory”

Ivory is a beautiful hard, white material that people get from the tusks or teeth of very large animals such as elephants or walruses. Alternate translation: “container made from tusks” or “container made from valuable animal teeth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
Marble is a precious stone that is used for building and to make statues, furniture, and many other things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
Cinnamon is a spice that smells nice and comes from the bark of a certain kind of tree.
Spice is a substance used to add flavor to food or a good smell to oil.
The **autumn fruit** refers to fruit that ripens in the fall. Here, it is a metaphor for “result” or “outcome.” Alternate translation: “result” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “what you wanted very much”

Quote: ἀπώλετο ἀπὸ σοῦ, καὶ οὐκέτι οὐ μὴ αὐτὰ εὑρήσουσιν
Note: Not to **be found** stands for not existing. Alternate translation: “has vanished, and they will never exist again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἀπώλετο ἀπὸ σοῦ, καὶ οὐκέτι οὐ μὴ αὐτὰ εὑρήσουσιν
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this figure of speech, you can state it in active form. Alternate translation: “has vanished; you will never have them again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: διὰ τὸν φόβον τοῦ βασανισμοῦ αὐτῆς
Note: If your readers would misunderstand the abstract nouns **fear** and **torment**, you can express them as verbs. Alternate translation: “because they will be afraid of God tormenting them they way he torments her” or “because they will be afraid of suffering the way she is suffering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The merchants are the ones who will be **weeping and mourning loudly**. Alternate translation: “and the merchants will weep and mourn loudly”

Quote: ἡ πόλις ἡ μεγάλη, ἡ περιβεβλημένη βύσσινον
Note: Throughout this chapter, Babylon is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “the great city, which was like a woman dressed in fine linen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἡ πόλις ἡ μεγάλη, ἡ περιβεβλημένη βύσσινον
Note: The merchants speak of Babylon as being **dressed in fine linen** because its people were dressed in fine linen. Alternate translation: “the great city, whose women were dressed in fine linen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “that wore fine linen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “adorned herself with gold” or “adorned themselves with gold” or “wore gold” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Alternate translation: “valuable gems” or “treasured gems”

Pearls are beautiful and valuable white beads that are formed inside the shell of a certain kind of small animal that lives in the ocean. See how you translated this in [Revelation 17:4](../17/04.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

The phrase **work the sea** refers to what they do on the sea. Alternate translation: “who travel on the sea to make their living” or “who sail on the sea to different places in order to trade things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: τίς ὁμοία τῇ πόλει τῇ μεγάλῃ?
Note: This question shows the people the importance of the **city** of Babylon. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you could translate it as a statement. Alternate translation: “No other city is like the great city, Babylon!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: ἔκρινεν ὁ Θεὸς τὸ κρίμα ὑμῶν ἐξ αὐτῆς
Note: If your readers would misunderstand the abstract noun **judgment**, you can express it with the verb “judge.” Alternate translation: “God has judged her for you” or “God has judged her because of the bad things she did to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nAnother angel begins to speak about Babylon. This is a different angel than the ones who have spoken previously.
A **millstone** large round stone used to crush grain.

Quote: ὁρμήματι βληθήσεται Βαβυλὼν ἡ μεγάλη πόλις, καὶ οὐ μὴ εὑρεθῇ ἔτι
Note: To be **thrown down** and **not be seen anymore** speaks of complete destruction of the **city**. Alternate translation: “Babylon will be completely destroyed and will no longer exist” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ὁρμήματι βληθήσεται Βαβυλὼν ἡ μεγάλη πόλις, καὶ οὐ μὴ εὑρεθῇ ἔτι
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “God will violently throw down Babylon, the great city, and it will no longer exist” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Not being **seen** here means that it will not exist. Alternate translation: “it will not exist anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: φωνὴ κιθαρῳδῶν, καὶ μουσικῶν, καὶ αὐλητῶν, καὶ σαλπιστῶν, οὐ μὴ ἀκουσθῇ ἐν σοὶ ἔτι
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “no one in your city will ever again hear the sound that harpists, musicians, flute players, and trumpeters make” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
The angel speaks as if Babylon were there listening to him. Alternate translation: “in Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])

Quote: οὐ μὴ ἀκουσθῇ ἐν σοὶ ἔτι
Note: Not being **heard** here means that they will not be there. Alternate translation: “they will not be in your city anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: πᾶς τεχνίτης οὐ μὴ εὑρεθῇ ἐν σοὶ
Note: Not being **found** there means that they will not be there. Alternate translation: “no craftsman of any kind will be in your city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: φωνὴ μύλου οὐ μὴ ἀκουσθῇ ἐν σοὶ ἔτι
Note: The sound of something not being **heard** means that no one will make that sound. Alternate translation: “no one will use a mill in your city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nThe angel who threw the millstone finishes talking.

Quote: φωνὴ νυμφίου καὶ νύμφης οὐ μὴ ἀκουσθῇ ἐν σοὶ ἔτι
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “no one will ever again hear in Babylon the happy voices of a bridegroom and a bride” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: οὐ μὴ ἀκουσθῇ ἐν σοὶ ἔτι
Note: Not being **heard** here means that they will not be there. Alternate translation: “will not be in your city anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: οἱ ἔμποροί σου ἦσαν οἱ μεγιστᾶνες τῆς γῆς
Note: The angel speaks of important and powerful people as if they were **princes**. Alternate translation: “your merchants were like princes of the earth” or “your merchants were the most important men in the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἐν τῇ φαρμακείᾳ σου ἐπλανήθησαν πάντα τὰ ἔθνη
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “you deceived the people of the nations with your magic spells” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ἐν αὐτῇ αἷμα προφητῶν καὶ ἁγίων εὑρέθη, καὶ πάντων τῶν ἐσφαγμένων ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς
Note: Here, **blood** being **found** means that the people of the city were guilty of killing people. Alternate translation: “in her is the guilt for the death of the prophets and saints, along with all the other people in the world who were killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: ἐν αὐτῇ αἷμα προφητῶν καὶ ἁγίων εὑρέθη, καὶ πάντων τῶν ἐσφαγμένων ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “Babylon is guilty of killing the prophets and believers and all the other people in the world who were killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Revelation 19 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The beginning of chapter 19 concludes the topic of Babylon falling.

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 1-8.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Songs

The Book of Revelation often describes heaven as a place where people sing. They worship God with songs. This illustrates that heaven is a place where God is always worshiped. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]])

### Wedding celebration

The wedding celebration or feast is an important image in Scripture. Jewish culture often pictured paradise, or life with God after death, as a feast. Here, the wedding feast is for the Lamb, who is Jesus, and his bride, who is all his people.
# General Information:\n\nThis is the next part of John’s vision. Here he describes the rejoicing in heaven over the fall of the great prostitute, who is the city of Babylon.
Here, **I** refers to John.
The word **Hallelujah** means “Praise God” or “Let us praise God.”

Here John refers to the city of Babylon whose wicked people rule over all the people of the earth and lead them to worship false gods. He speaks of the wicked people of Babylon as if they were a **great prostitute**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here, **the earth** is a metonym for its inhabitants. Alternate translation: “who corrupted the people of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here, **the blood** is a metonym that represents murder. Alternate translation: “the murder of his servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here, **he** refers to Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
Here, **they** refers to the crowd of people in heaven.
The word **Hallelujah** means “Praise God” or “Let us praise God.” See how you translated this in [Revelation 19:1](../19/01.md).

The word **her** refers to the city of Babylon, which is spoken of as if it were a prostitute. The **smoke** is from the fire that destroys the city. Alternate translation: “smoke rises from that city”
See how you translated this in [Revelation 4:4](../04/04.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
See how you translated this in [Revelation 4:6](../04/06.md) Alternate translation: “the four living beings” or “the four living things”
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “who sat on the throne” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here John speaks of a **voice** as if it were a person. Alternate translation: “someone spoke from the throne” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Here, **our** refers to the speaker and all God’s servants. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
Here, **fear** does not mean to be afraid of God, but to honor him. Alternate translation: “all you who honor him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
The speaker uses the words **small** and **great** together to include all of God’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: καὶ ἤκουσα ὡς φωνὴν ὄχλου πολλοῦ, καὶ ὡς φωνὴν ὑδάτων πολλῶν, καὶ ὡς φωνὴν βροντῶν ἰσχυρῶν
Note: John speaks of what he is hearing as if it were like the sound made by a very large **crowd** of people, a large body of rushing water, and very loud **thunder**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The word **Hallelujah** means “Praise God” or “Let us praise God.” See how you translated this in [Revelation 19:1](../19/01.md).
Alternate translation: “Because the Lord”
# Connecting Statement:\n\nThe voice of the crowd from the previous verse continues speaking.
Here, **us** refers to all of God’s servants.
Alternate translation: “give God the glory” or “honor God”

Quote: ὁ γάμος τοῦ Ἀρνίου & ἡ γυνὴ αὐτοῦ ἡτοίμασεν ἑαυτήν
Note: Here John speaks of the joining of Jesus and his people together forever as if it were a **wedding celebration** and his people were **his bride**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
A lamb is a young sheep. Here, **the Lamb** used symbolically to refer to Christ. See how you translated this in [Revelation 5:6](../05/06.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
Existing in the present is spoken of as having **come**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
John speaks of God’s people as if they were a **bride** who has gotten **herself ready** for her wedding. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἐδόθη αὐτῇ ἵνα περιβάληται βύσσινον λαμπρὸν καθαρόν
Note: Here, **her** and **she** refer to the people of God. John speaks of the righteous acts of God’s people as if they were a bright and clean dress that a bride wears on her wedding day. Alternate translation: “and it was permitted to them to wear a dress of bright and clean fine linen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἐδόθη αὐτῇ ἵνα περιβάληται βύσσινον λαμπρὸν καθαρόν
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “God allowed her to wear a dress of bright and clean fine linen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
# General Information:\n\nAn angel begins to speak to John. This is likely the same angel who began to speak to John in [Revelation 17:1](../17/01.md).
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “the people whom God invites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: τὸ δεῖπνον τοῦ γάμου τοῦ Ἀρνίου
Note: Here the angel speaks of the joining of Jesus and his people forever as if it were a **wedding supper**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This means that John purposely lay on the ground and stretched himself out in reverence or submission. This action was an important part of worship, to show respect and willingness to serve. See note in [Revelation 19:3](../19/03.md).
Here the word **brothers** here refers to all believers, male and female.
Here holding stands for believing in or announcing. Alternate translation: “who speak the truth about Jesus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ἡ γὰρ μαρτυρία Ἰησοῦ ἐστιν τὸ πνεῦμα τῆς προφητείας
Note: Here, **the spirit of prophecy** refers to God’s Holy Spirit. Alternate translation: “for it is the Spirit of God who gives people the power to speak the truth about Jesus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
# General Information:\n\nThis is the beginning of a new vision. John begins to describe a rider on a white horse.

This imagery is used to signify the beginning of a new vision. See how you translated this idea in [Revelation 4:1](../04/01.md) and [Revelation 11:19](../11/19.md) and [Revelation 15:5](../15/05.md).
The rider is Jesus.
Here, **righteousness** refers to what is right. Alternate translation: “he judges all people and wages war according to what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
John speaks of the rider’s **eyes** as if they shone like a **flame** of fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “and someone has written a name on him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ὃ οὐδεὶς οἶδεν, εἰ μὴ αὐτός
Note: Here, **except himself** means that he is the only one. Alternate translation: “on him, and only he knows the meaning of that name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “and blood had covered his robe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: κέκληται τὸ ὄνομα αὐτοῦ, ὁ λόγος τοῦ Θεοῦ
Note: Here, **Word of God** is a metonym for Jesus Christ. Alternate translation: “his name is called the Message of God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: κέκληται τὸ ὄνομα αὐτοῦ, ὁ λόγος τοῦ Θεοῦ
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “his name is also the Word of God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ἐκ τοῦ στόματος αὐτοῦ ἐκπορεύεται ῥομφαία ὀξεῖα
Note: The **sword** blade was sticking out of **his mouth**. The sword itself was not in motion. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Revelation 1:16](../01/16.md).
Alternate translation: “he could destroy the nations” or “he could bring the nations under his control”
John speaks of the rider’s power as if he were ruling with **an iron rod**. See how you translated this in [Revelation 12:5](../12/05.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: αὐτὸς πατεῖ τὴν ληνὸν τοῦ οἴνου τοῦ θυμοῦ τῆς ὀργῆς τοῦ Θεοῦ τοῦ Παντοκράτορος
Note: John speaks of the rider’s destroying his enemies as if they were grapes that a person **tramples** in a **winepress**. Alternate translation: “he crushes his enemies according to the wrath of God Almighty, just as a person crushes grapes in a winepress” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: αὐτὸς πατεῖ τὴν ληνὸν τοῦ οἴνου τοῦ θυμοῦ τῆς ὀργῆς τοῦ Θεοῦ τοῦ Παντοκράτορος
Note: Here, **wrath** refers to God’s punishment of evil persons. Alternate translation: “he crushes his enemies according to the judgment of God Almighty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: ἔχει ἐπὶ τὸ ἱμάτιον καὶ ἐπὶ τὸν μηρὸν αὐτοῦ, ὄνομα γεγραμμένον
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “someone has written a name on his robe and thigh:” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: εἶδον ἕνα ἄγγελον ἑστῶτα ἐν τῷ ἡλίῳ
Note: Here, **the sun** is a metonym for the light of the sun. Alternate translation: “Then I saw an angel standing in the light of the sun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: ἐλευθέρων τε καὶ δούλων, καὶ μικρῶν καὶ μεγάλων
Note: The angel uses these two sets of opposite-meaning words together to refer to all people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: ἐπιάσθη τὸ θηρίον, καὶ μετ’ αὐτοῦ ὁ ψευδοπροφήτης
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “the rider on the white horse captured the beast and the false prophet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
The **mark of the beast** was an identifying mark that indicated that the person who received it worshiped the beast. See how you translated this in [Revelation 13:17](../13/17.md).

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “God threw the beast and the false prophet alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρὸς, τῆς καιομένης ἐν θείῳ
Note: Alternate translation: “place full of fire that burns with sulfur”

# Revelation 20 General Notes

## Special concepts in this chapter

### The thousand-year reign of Christ

In this chapter, Jesus is said to reign for a thousand years, at the same time that Satan is bound. Scholars are divided over whether this refers to a future period of time or to Jesus reigning now from heaven. It is not necessary to understand this passage in order to translate it accurately. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

### Final rebellion

This chapter also describes what happens after the thousand years are ended. During this time, Satan and many people will attempt to rebel against Jesus. This will result in God’s ultimate and final victory over sin and evil. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/eternity]])

### Great white throne

This chapter ends with God judging all people who ever lived. God separates people who believe in Jesus from those who do not believe in him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Book of Life

This is a metaphor for eternal life. Those possessing eternal life are said to have their names written in this Book of Life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Hades and the lake of fire

These appear to be two distinct places. The translator may wish to do further research to determine how to translate these two places differently. They should not be made the same as each other in translation. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/hell]])

# Revelation 21 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

This chapter gives a detailed picture of the new Jerusalem.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Second death

Death is a type of separation. The first death is physically dying, when the soul is separated from the body. The second death is being eternally separated from God. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/death]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/soul]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/eternity]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Book of Life

This is a metaphor for eternal life. Those possessing eternal life are said to have their names written in this Book of Life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### New heaven and new earth

It is unclear whether this is an entirely new heaven and earth or if it is remade out of the present heaven and earth. The same is also true of the new Jerusalem. It is possible this will affect translation in some languages. The word “new” in the original language means different and better than the old. It does not mean new in time.

# Revelation 22 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

This chapter emphasizes that Jesus is coming soon.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Tree of life

There is probably an intended connection between the tree of life in the Garden of Eden and the tree of life mentioned in this chapter. The curse that began in Eden will end at this time.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Alpha and omega

These are the names of the first and last letters in the Greek alphabet. The ULT spells out their names in English. This strategy can serve as a model for translators. Some translators, however, may decide to use the first and last letters in their own alphabet. This would be “A and Z” in English.

Alternate translation: “the A and the Z, the first and the last, the beginning and the end” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

This could refer to: (1) the one who began all things and who ends all things. (2) the one who has always lived and who always will live. If your readers would misunderstand this, you may consider using the first and last letters of your alphabet. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to the eternal nature of Jesus. See how you translated this in [Revelation 1:17](../01/17.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This could refer to: (1) the one who began all things and the one who will cause all things to end. (2) the one who existed before all things and who will exist after all things. See how you translated this in [Revelation 21:6](../21/06.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Becoming righteous is spoken of as if it were washing one’s clothing. See how you translated as similar phrase in [Revelation 7:14](../07/14.md). Alternate translation: “those who have become righteous, as if they have washed their robes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This means they are outside the city and not allowed to enter.
In that culture, **dogs** were considered to be unclean, despised animals. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here the word **dogs** is derogatory and refers to people who are wicked. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the word **you** is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: ἡ ῥίζα καὶ τὸ γένος Δαυείδ
Note: The words **root** and **descendant** mean basically the same thing. Together the words emphasize that Jesus belongs to the family of David. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: ἡ ῥίζα καὶ τὸ γένος Δαυείδ
Note: Jesus speaks of being a **descendant** as if he were a **root** that grew out of David. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: ὁ ἀστὴρ ὁ λαμπρός, ὁ πρωϊνός
Note: Jesus speaks of himself as if he were the **bright** **star** that sometimes appears early in the **morning** and indicates that a new day is about to begin. See how you translated “morning star” in [Revelation 2:28](../02/28.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nThis verse is a response to what Jesus said.
Believers are spoken of as if they were a **Bride** about to be married to her groom, Jesus. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here, **Come** could mean: (1) this is an invitation for people to come and drink the water of life. Alternate translation: “Come and drink!” (2) this is a polite request for Jesus to return. Alternate translation: “Please come!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: ὁ διψῶν ἐρχέσθω; ὁ θέλων λαβέτω ὕδωρ ζωῆς δωρεάν
Note: A person’s desire for eternal **life** is spoken of as if it were thirst and of that person receiving eternal life as if he were drinking life-giving **water**. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Eternal **life** is spoken of as if it were provided by life-giving **water**. See how you translated this in [Revelation 21:6](../21/06.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nJohn gives his final remarks about the book of Revelation.
Here, **I** refers to John.

Quote: τοὺς λόγους τῆς προφητείας τοῦ βιβλίου τούτου
Note: Here, **the words** refers to the message that they formed. See how you translated this in [Revelation 22:7](../22/07.md). Alternate translation: “this prophetic message of this book” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: ἐάν τις ἐπιθῇ ἐπ’ αὐτά, ἐπιθήσει ὁ Θεὸς ἐπ’ αὐτὸν τὰς πληγὰς τὰς γεγραμμένας ἐν τῷ βιβλίῳ τούτῳ
Note: This is a strong warning to not change anything about this prophecy.

Quote: τὰς γεγραμμένας ἐν τῷ βιβλίῳ τούτῳ
Note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “which I have written about in this book” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: ἐάν τις ἀφέλῃ ἀπὸ τῶν λόγων τοῦ βιβλίου τῆς προφητείας ταύτης, ἀφελεῖ ὁ Θεὸς τὸ μέρος αὐτοῦ ἀπὸ τοῦ ξύλου τῆς ζωῆς καὶ ἐκ τῆς πόλεως τῆς ἁγίας, τῶν γεγραμμένων ἐν τῷ βιβλίῳ τούτῳ
Note: This is a strong warning to not change anything about this prophecy.
# General Information:\n\nIn these verses John gives his and Jesus’ closing greetings.
Alternate translation: “Jesus, who testifies”
